First, the argument that cell phones CAN'T cause cancer because the non-ionizing radiation they emit is known not to cause cellular damage, is unscientific deductive reasoning. The human body is a complex system with countless apparently random and unpredictable interactions that we haven't even begun to understand, because there are so many variables and we can't do controlled experiments on the general population. So to suggest that we know definitively all the effects on the human body of exposure to a given thing is disingenuous. There's not a single thing we are exposed to that we know, for sure, is completely without risk; just look at the ever-changing headlines about which foods will give you cancer or extend your life if you don't believe me. It's possible to isolate a specific thing as being definitely toxic or carcinogenic, if the signal is strong enough, but a lack of a detectable signal doesn't rule out a possible detrimental effect that is simply not frequent enough - or not immediate enough - to definitively pin on the thing being investigated. This is especially true for carcinogens, which appear harmless in the short term only to result in inexplicable tumors decades into the future, obscuring any obvious chain of causation. In fact, independent (ie not funded by the wireless industry) research, based on actual experiments exposing rats to cell phone radiation, DOES strongly suggest that it causes cancer (at least in rats). Now we can scratch our heads and wonder how it does that, because we always thought that non-ionizing radiation wasn't strong enough to cause cell damage. But we would be fools to dismiss the findings as irrelevant simply because we already know them to be impossible.

Second, the very question of whether cell phones cause brain cancer is a red herring. Cell phones do not emit radiation only when you're holding them next to your head. Today's smart phones, especially, are constantly talking to nearby cell towers (not to mention GPS satellites) unless they are turned off or in airplane mode. Most of that time, your phone is not against your head - it's in your pocket, or in your lap, or in your hands in front of you. So what makes people think that brain cancer is the main thing you need to worry about a cell phone causing? I've thought for years that the most likely effect these phones are having on people is reproductive, since most people carry them in their pants pockets, meaning your genital region is absorbing the brunt of any radiation leaking off your phone during the 10+ hours a day you're carrying it around. And don't forget about the hours you're asleep. How many people put their phone in airplane mode for the night? Versus the number who sleep with it next to their bed, just inches away from their body?

One thing Derek is right about - it's nearly impossible to do a real controlled study on the general population, because cell phones are so ubiquitous. Even if you don't own one, you likely spend a good portion of your day near other people's phones, either at work, or on public transportation, or when socializing with friends and family. (Just try asking someone you're with if they woudln't mind moving their phone so that it's not inches away from you (or your child) and watch the blank looks they give you; it's as if you're speaking a different language. I wonder if this is the reaction you would have gotten in the 50s if you'd asked someone to take their cigarette outside.) But you can still do studies on lab animals. Now you can argue that causing cancer in rats don't necessarily translate to causing cancer in humans, and in general that's true. But I go by the precautionary principle. Absence of proof isn't proof of absence - especially when evidence is in such abundance.

While I'm glad some people are finally starting to speak out against the wireless industry's whitewashing spokesmen, who follow in the footsteps of Big Tobacco and Big Oil in sowing doubt about the growing evidence of the disastrous side effects (cancer and climate change, respectively) of their industries, I'm always astounded by the willingness of otherwise intelligent people, including scientists, to dismiss seemingly rational concerns about the health effects of untested new products as fear mongering and hysteria, when there is such an obvious financial incentive behind the reassurances of safety by those selling the product. Do we really love our phones that much, that we're willing to cover our own eyes and tell ourselves everything must be ok? Or are we terrified of admitting to ourselves that we might have already done irreparable damage to our bodies and our children's bodies? Or do we just need to have faith in our institutions, to believe that our government is protecting us, and that regulatory agencies are doing their jobs and haven't been captured by the industries on the other side of that revolving door?

I would love to hear an update on this, given that old research is finally seeing the light of day. As always, the hallmark of science is being able to reassess one's previously held assumptions in the light of new evidence and admit that one might have been wrong.
